Award.AwardTitle: Connecting Nanoscale Structure and Plasticity in Bulk Metallic Glasses

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to connect structure to plastic deformation in bulk metallic glasses (BMGs). Experiments with fluctuation electron microscopy (FEM) will be used to measure nanoscale medium-range order in BMGs. The FEM data will be combined with an empirical interatomic potential in a hybrid Reverse Monte Carlo structural refinement, producing models with realistic short- and
medium-range structure. Research on Pd-Si BMGs will provide an essential test of the generality of a recently proposed structural model
for Zr-Cu-Al BMGs that consists of nanometer-regions with crystal-like and icosahedral-like internal structure. If crystal-like nanometer scale regions are a general feature of BMG structure, it could have significant impact on models of their plastic flow.

If successful, this research will lay the fundamental scientific groundwork for expanded applications of BMG alloys, by eventually assisting design of new alloys with desired mechanical and glass-forming characteristics through detailed understanding of their structure and its connection to plasticity. The research team will involve undergraduate and graduate students, especially from under-represented groups, and will engage the general public and K-12 students in the excitement and outcomes of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in new understanding of how atoms fit together inside metallic glass alloys.  One of the basic rules of materials science is if we know where the atoms are, we can predict the properties and uses of materials, so future research may use the new understanding generated by this project to help create advanced metallic glass alloys with desirable properties.  We also created a new combined experimental / computational method for discovering atomic structure information for complex materials, which will be used for further studies of different glasses and maybe other nano- or biomaterials in the future.

The project has also resulted in new understanding of how metallic glasses plastically deform under stress or pressure. In this context "plastic deformation" means irrecoverable deformation in much the same way that a coiled spring, if stretched too far, won't return to its original length.  In metallic glasses plastic deformation concentrates along narrow bands of shear, much like the fault lines that form in the earth's crust during earth quakes but at far smaller length scales. Inside these shear bands the atoms all slide past each other during plastic deformation.  Our experiments indicate how it might be possible to separately probe shear band initiation and shear band sliding and connect each of these back to the underlying atomistic processes.  The better we understand these processes and their relation to atomic structure, the better we will be able to design advanced metallic glasses. 


Last Modified: 12/30/2015
Modified by: Donald S Stone

Image
  • a) Illustration of diamond indenter probing the plastic deformation ("hardness") of a metallic glass ingot. b) Scanning electron micrograph of hardness impressions in the cross section of a 2 mm diameter, Zr50Cu45Al5 metallic glass ingot. Indents are about 2.5 micrometers across.
    Z.H. Melgarejo and D.S. Stone
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Donald S Stone
    Hardness measurements of plasticity in metallic glass

In metallic glasses plastic deformation concentrates along narrow bands of shear, much like the fault lines that form in the earth's crust during earth quakes but at far smaller length scales. Inside these shear bands the atoms all slide past each other during plastic deformation.
